intro: Rhinanthus major subsp. glaber, commonly known as the glabrous yellow rattle, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, known for its parasitic relationships with grasses. The plant is characterized by its yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It typically grows in open grasslands and disturbed soils, often in dry or sandy habitats. The subspecies glaber is distinguished by its smooth, hairless stems and leaves, setting it apart from other subspecies of Rhinanthus major.
